translation: The words of the Preacher, son of David, king in Jerusalem.
Vanity of vanities, says the Preacher, vanity of vanities; all is vanity.
What profit has a man in all his toil wherein he labors under the sun?
One generation goes, and another generation comes, but the earth stands forever.
The sun rises, and the sun sets, and hastens to its place; there it rises again.
Going toward the south and turning toward the north, turning, turning goes the wind, and on its circuits the wind returns.
All the streams go to the sea, yet the sea is not full; to the place where the streams go, there they return to go again.
All things are wearisome; man is not able to utter it. The eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
That which has been is that which shall be, and that which has been done is that which shall be done; and there is nothing new under the sun.
There is a thing of which one will say, “See, this is new.” It has already been in ages long before us.
There is no remembrance of former things, and also of later things that shall be, there will be for them no remembrance among those who shall be afterward.
I, the Preacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
And I set my heart to seek and to search out by wisdom all that is done under the heavens; it is a grievous task that God has given to the sons of man to be afflicted with.
I have seen all the works that are done under the sun, and behold, all is vanity and a striving after wind.
That which is crooked cannot be made straight, and that which is lacking cannot be counted.
I spoke with my heart, saying, I, behold, I have grown great and increased in wisdom more than all who were before me over Jerusalem, and my heart has seen much wisdom and knowledge.
And I set my heart to know wisdom, and to know madness and folly; I perceived that this also is a chasing after the wind.
For in much wisdom is much vexation, and he who increases knowledge increases sorrow.
I said in my heart, “Come now, I will test you with mirth; therefore enjoy goodness.” But behold, this also is vanity.
Of laughter I said, It is madness; and of joy, What does it accomplish?

I searched in my heart to cheer my flesh with wine, while my heart yet guided me with wisdom, and to lay hold on folly, till I might see what is good for the sons of man to do under the heavens all the number of the days of their life.
I made great works for myself; I built houses for myself, I planted vineyards for myself.
I made for myself gardens and orchards, and I planted in them trees of every kind of fruit.
I made for myself pools of water, to water from them a forest sprouting with trees.
I acquired male and female servants, and had servants born in my house; I also had great possessions of herds and flocks, more than all who had been before me in Jerusalem.

I also gathered for myself silver and gold, and the treasure of kings and of the provinces; I made for myself male singers and female singers, and the delights of the sons of man, a concubine and concubines.
So I became great and increased more than all who had been before me in Jerusalem; also my wisdom remained with me.
And all that my eyes desired I did not withhold from them; I did not restrain my heart from any joy, for my heart rejoiced in all my labor, and this was my portion from all my labor.
Then I turned to all the works that my hands had done, and to the labor in which I had toiled to do them; and behold, all is vanity and a striving after wind, and there is no profit under the sun.
And I turned myself to behold wisdom, and madness, and folly; for what is the man that shall come after the king, even that which has already been done?
And I saw that there is advantage in wisdom over folly, as there is advantage in light over darkness.
The wise man, his eyes are in his head, but the fool walks in darkness; yet I also perceived that one event happens to them all.
And I said in my heart, As it happens to the fool, so it will happen also to me; and why was I then more wise? And I spoke in my heart, that this also is vanity.
For there is no remembrance of the wise more than of the fool forever, since in the days to come all will be forgotten. And how does the wise man die? Just like the fool.
And I hated life, because the work that is done under the sun was grievous to me; for all is vanity and a striving after wind.
And I hated all my toil in which I toil under the sun, because I must leave it to the man who shall be after me.
And who knows whether he will be wise or a fool? Yet he will rule over all my labor wherein I have labored, and wherein I have shown myself wise under the sun. This also is vanity.
So I turned about, I myself, to cause my heart to despair over all the toil wherein I had labored under the sun.
For there is a man whose toil is with wisdom and with knowledge and with skill, yet to a man who has not toiled for it he must give his portion; this also is vanity and a great evil.
For what has a man for all his toil and the striving of his heart with which he labors under the sun?
For all his days are sorrows, and his travail vexation; even in the night his heart does not lie down. This also is vanity.
There is nothing better for a man than that he should eat and drink, and that he should make his soul see good in his labor. This also I have seen, that it is from the hand of God.
For who can eat, or who can enjoy, apart from me?

For to the man who is good before Him He has given wisdom and knowledge and joy, but to the sinner He has given the task to gather and to heap up, to give to him who is good before God; this also is vanity and a chasing after wind.
For everything there is a season, and a time for every purpose under heaven.
A time to be born, and a time to die; a time to plant, and a time to uproot what is planted.
A time to kill, and a time to heal; a time to break down, and a time to build up.
A time to weep, and a time to laugh; a time to mourn, and a time to dance.
A time to cast away stones, and a time to gather stones together; a time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing.
A time to seek, and a time to lose; a time to keep, and a time to cast away.
A time to tear, and a time to sew; a time to keep silence, and a time to speak.
A time to love, and a time to hate; a time for war, and a time for peace.
What profit has the worker in that wherein he labors?
I have seen the task which God has given to the children of man to be occupied with it.
He has made everything beautiful in its time; He has also set eternity in their heart, yet so that man cannot find out the work that God has done from the beginning to the end.
I know that there is nothing better for them than to rejoice and to do good in his life.
And also, every man who eats and drinks and sees good in all his toil, it is the gift of God.
I know that whatever God does, it shall be forever; nothing can be added to it, and nothing can be taken from it. And God has done this, that they should fear before Him.
That which has been is already, and that which is to be has already been; and God seeks out what is pursued.
And moreover I saw under the sun the place of judgment, that there was wickedness there; and the place of righteousness, that there was wickedness there.
I said in my heart, God will judge the righteous and the wicked; for there is a time for every purpose and for every work there.
I said in my heart concerning the sons of man, that God is testing them, to show them that they themselves are but beasts.

For the fate of the sons of man and the fate of the beast is one and the same; as this one dies, so dies that one, and one breath is in them all, and man has no advantage over the beast, for all is vanity.
All go to one place; all are from the dust, and all return to the dust.
Who knows the spirit of the children of man, whether it goes upward, and the spirit of the beast, whether it goes downward to the earth?
And I saw that there is nothing better than that a man should rejoice in his works, for that is his portion; for who shall bring him to see what shall be after him?

And I returned and saw all the oppressions that are done under the sun; and behold, the tears of the oppressed, and they have no comforter; and in the hand of their oppressors is power, but they have no comforter.
And I praised the dead who are already dead more than the living who are still alive.
But better than both of them is he who has not yet been, who has not seen the evil work that is done under the sun.
And I saw that all toil and every skillful work is the envy of a man from his neighbor; this also is vanity and a chasing after wind.
The fool folds his hands and consumes his own flesh.
Better is a handful with quietness than two handfuls with toil and a chasing after wind.
Then I returned and saw vanity under the sun.

There is one, and there is not a second; he has neither son nor brother, yet there is no end to all his toil, and his eye is not satisfied with riches. And for whom, then, do I labor and deprive my soul of good? This also is vanity, and it is a grievous business.
Two are better than one, because they have a good reward for their labor.
For if they fall, the one will lift up his companion; but woe to him who is alone when he falls, and there is not a second to raise him up.
Again, if two lie down together, then they have warmth; but how can one be warm alone?
And if one might prevail against him, two shall withstand him; and a threefold cord is not quickly broken.
Better is a poor and wise youth than an old and foolish king who no longer knows how to be warned.
For out of the house of prisoners he came forth to reign, even though in his kingdom he was born poor.
I saw all the living who walk under the sun, with the second youth who shall stand in his place.
There is no end of all the people, of all that have been before them; yet those who come after shall not rejoice in him. Surely this also is vanity and a chasing after wind.
Guard your steps when you go to the house of God, and draw near to listen rather than to offer the sacrifice of fools, for they do not know that they are doing evil.
Do not be hasty with your mouth, and let your heart not hurry to bring forth a word before God; for God is in heaven and you are upon the earth; therefore let your words be few.
For the dream comes through much busyness, and the voice of a fool through many words.
When you vow a vow to God, do not delay to pay it, for he has no pleasure in fools; pay what you vow.
Better that you should not vow, than that you should vow and not pay.
Do not let your mouth cause your flesh to sin, and do not say before the messenger that it was a mistake. Why should God be angry at your voice and destroy the work of your hands?
For in the multitude of dreams and vanities and many words, rather fear God.

If you see in a province the oppression of the poor, and the robbery of justice and righteousness, do not marvel at the matter; for one higher than the high watches, and there are higher ones over them.
But the profit of the land in all things is this: a king himself is served by the field.
He who loves silver shall not be satisfied with silver, and whoever loves abundance, with increase; this also is vanity.
When goods increase, those who consume them increase; and what advantage is there to their owner, except the beholding of them with his eyes?
Sweet is the sleep of the laborer, whether he eats little or much; but the abundance of the rich does not let him sleep.
There is a grievous evil that I have seen under the sun: riches kept by their owner to his own hurt.
And that riches perished in an evil business, and he begot a son, and there was nothing in his hand.
As he came forth from his mother’s womb, naked shall he return to go as he came, and he shall carry nothing away from his toil that he may take in his hand.
And this also is a grievous evil: exactly as he came, so shall he go; and what profit has he that he labors for the wind?
Also all his days he eats in darkness, and he is much vexed, and has sickness and wrath.

Behold, what I have seen to be good and fitting is to eat and to drink, and to see good in all his toil with which he toils under the sun, the number of the days of his life which God has given him, for this is his portion.
Also, every man to whom God has given riches and possessions, and has empowered him to eat of them, and to take his portion, and to rejoice in his toil—this is the gift of God.
For he will not much remember the days of his life, because God keeps him occupied with the gladness of his heart.
There is an evil which I have seen under the sun, and it lies heavy upon man.

A man to whom God gives riches and possessions and honor, so that he lacks nothing for his soul of all that he desires, yet God does not empower him to eat of it, but a foreign man shall eat it—this is vanity, and it is a grievous affliction.

If a man begets a hundred children and lives many years, and the days of his years are many, yet his soul is not satisfied with good, and he also has no burial, I say that a stillborn child is better off than he.
For in vanity it comes, and in darkness it departs, and in darkness its name is covered.
Moreover it has not seen the sun nor known anything; this one has rest rather than that.
Even if he live a thousand years twice over, yet see no good, do not all go to one place?
All the toil of man is for his mouth, yet the soul is not satisfied.
For what advantage has the wise more than the fool? What does the poor man know, how to walk before the living?
Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of desire; this also is vanity and a striving after wind.
That which has been, its name has already been called, and it is known that he is man; and he is not able to contend with Him who is mightier than he.
For there are many words that increase vanity; what advantage has man?
For who knows what is good for a man in life, all the number of the days of his vain life which he spends like a shadow? For who can tell a man what shall be after him under the sun?
A good name is better than precious oil, and the day of death than the day of one’s birth.
It is better to go to the house of mourning than to go to the house of feasting, for that is the end of all mankind, and the living will lay it to heart.
Better is sorrow than laughter, for by the sadness of the face the heart is made good.
The heart of the wise is in the house of mourning, but the heart of fools is in the house of mirth.
It is better to hear the rebuke of the wise than for a man to listen to the song of fools.
For like the crackling of thorns under a pot, so is the laughter of the fool; this also is vanity.
Surely oppression makes a wise man mad, and a bribe destroys the heart.
Better is the end of a matter than its beginning, and better is one who is patient in spirit than one who is proud in spirit.
Do not be quick in your spirit to be angry, for anger rests in the bosom of fools.
Do not say, “How is it that the former days were better than these?” For it is not from wisdom that you ask concerning this.
Wisdom is good with an inheritance, and is an advantage to those who see the sun.
For wisdom is a shelter as money is a shelter, but the advantage of knowledge is this: wisdom gives life to those who possess it.
Consider the work of God, for who is able to make straight what He has made crooked?
In the day of prosperity be joyful, and in the day of adversity consider: surely this also, set over against that, has God made, so that man should not find out anything that shall be after him.
All this I have seen in the days of my vanity: there is a righteous man who perishes in his righteousness, and there is a wicked man who prolongs his days in his evil.
Do not be overly righteous, and do not make yourself too wise; why should you destroy yourself?
Do not be exceedingly wicked, and do not be foolish; why should you die before your time?
It is good that you take hold of this, and also from that do not let your hand rest, for the one who fears God will come forth with them all.
Wisdom strengthens the wise more than ten rulers who are in a city.
For there is no righteous man on earth who does good and does not sin.
Also, do not give your heart to all the words that are spoken, lest you hear your servant cursing you.
For you also know in your own heart that many times you yourself likewise have cursed others.
All this I tested with wisdom; I said, “I will be wise,” but it was far from me.
Far off is that which has been, and deep, very deep; who can find it out?
I turned, I and my heart, to know and to search out and to seek wisdom and reckoning, and to know wickedness as folly, and the foolishness of madness.
And I find more bitter than death the woman whose heart is snares and nets, and her hands are bonds. Whoever is good before God shall escape from her, but the sinner shall be taken by her.
See, this I have found, says the Preacher, adding one thing to another to find out the account.
That which my soul still sought, but I did not find: one man among a thousand I found, but a woman among all these I did not find.
Only, see, this I have found: that God made man upright, but they have sought out many devices.
Who is like the wise man, and who knows the interpretation of a matter? A man’s wisdom makes his face shine, and the hardness of his face is changed.
I say, keep the king’s command, and that on account of the oath of God.
Do not be hasty to go from his presence; do not stand in an evil matter, for he will do whatever he pleases.
Where the word of a king is, there is power; and who may say to him, What are you doing?
Whoever keeps the commandment shall know no evil thing, and the wise heart knows both time and judgment.
For to every purpose there is a time and a judgment, for the misery of man is great upon him.
For he does not know what shall be; for who can tell him how it shall be?
No man has power over the spirit to restrain the spirit, and there is no authority over the day of death; and there is no discharge in war, and wickedness will not deliver those who are given to it.
All this I have seen, and I set my heart to every work that is done under the sun: a time when man rules over man to his hurt.
So I saw the wicked buried and coming and going, and from the holy place they would walk, and they were forgotten in the city where they had so done; this also is vanity.
Because sentence against an evil deed is not carried out swiftly, therefore the heart of the children of man is fully set in them to do evil.
Though a sinner does evil a hundred times and prolongs his days, yet I also know that it shall be well with those who fear God, who fear before Him.
But it shall not be well with the wicked, neither shall he prolong his days like a shadow, because he does not fear before God.

There is a vanity that is done upon the earth: that there are righteous men to whom it happens according to the work of the wicked, and there are wicked men to whom it happens according to the work of the righteous. I said that this also is vanity.

So I commended joy, because there is nothing better for a man under the sun than to eat and to drink and to rejoice, and this will accompany him in his toil all the days of his life which God has given him under the sun.
When I applied my heart to know wisdom, and to see the business that is done upon the earth—for even by day and by night one’s eyes see no sleep—

And I saw all the work of God, that man is not able to find out the work that is done under the sun; because however much a man labors to seek it out, he shall not find it, and even though the wise man claims to know, he is not able to find it.

For all this I laid to heart, and to search out all this: that the righteous, and the wise, and their works are in the hand of God; whether it be love or hatred, man does not know; all lies before them.

All things come alike to all: one event happens to the righteous and to the wicked, to the good and to the pure and to the unclean, to him who sacrifices and to him who does not sacrifice; as the good, so is the sinner; he who swears is as he who fears an oath.

This is an evil in all that is done under the sun, that one event happens to all; and also the heart of the children of man is full of evil, and madness is in their heart while they live, and after that they go to the dead.
For whoever is joined to all the living, there is hope; for a living dog is better than a dead lion.
For the living know that they shall die, but the dead know nothing at all, and they have no more reward, for their memory is forgotten.
Also their love, and their hatred, and their envy, have already perished; and they have no more a portion forever in anything that is done under the sun.
Go, eat your bread with joy, and drink your wine with a glad heart, for God has already accepted your works.
At all times let your garments be white, and let not oil be lacking upon your head.

See life with the wife whom you love all the days of your vain life which He has given you under the sun, all the days of your vanity; for this is your portion in life and in your toil wherein you toil under the sun.
Whatever your hand finds to do, do it with your might; for there is no work, nor planning, nor knowledge, nor wisdom in Sheol, where you are going.

I returned and saw under the sun that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the mighty, nor yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favor to those who know; for time and chance happen to them all.

For man also does not know his time: like the fish that are caught in an evil net, and like the birds that are taken in a snare, so are the children of man ensnared in an evil time, when it falls upon them suddenly.
This also I saw as wisdom under the sun, and it was great to me.
A small city, and few men were in it; and there came against it a great king, and he surrounded it and built against it great siegeworks.
And there was found in it a poor wise man, and he by his wisdom delivered the city; yet no man remembered that same poor man.
Then I said, Wisdom is better than might; yet the poor man’s wisdom is despised, and his words are not heeded.
The words of the wise, heard in quiet, are better than the cry of him who rules among fools.
Wisdom is better than weapons of war, but one sinner destroys much good.
Dead flies make the perfumer’s oil give off a stench and bubble forth; so a little folly outweighs wisdom and honor.
The heart of the wise is at his right hand, but the heart of the fool at his left.
Also, when he walks along the way, a fool, his heart is lacking, and he says to everyone that he is a fool.
If the spirit of the ruler rises up against you, do not leave your place, for calmness lays to rest great offenses.
There is an evil I have seen under the sun, like an error that goes forth from before the ruler.
Folly is set in many high places, while the rich sit in a low estate.
I have seen servants upon horses, and princes walking upon the earth like servants.
He who digs a pit will fall into it, and he who breaks through a wall, a serpent will bite him.
He who quarries stones is hurt by them, and he who splits wood is endangered by them.
If the iron is dull and one does not sharpen the edge, then he must increase his strength; but wisdom brings success.
If the serpent bites before it is charmed, then there is no advantage to the master of the tongue.
The words of a wise man’s mouth are gracious, but the lips of a fool will swallow him up.
The beginning of the words of his mouth is foolishness, and the end of his talk is wicked madness.
And the fool multiplies words; yet no man knows what shall be, and what shall be after him, who can tell him?
The toil of fools wearies him, for he does not know how to go to the city.
Woe to you, O land, when your king is a youth, and your princes eat in the morning.
Blessed are you, O land, when your king is a son of nobles, and your princes eat at the proper time, for strength and not for drunkenness.
By slothfulness the roof sinks in, and through the lowering of the hands the house leaks.
Bread is made for laughter, and wine gladdens life, and money answers everything.
Even in your thought do not curse the king, and in your bedchambers do not curse the rich; for a bird of the heavens will carry the voice, and a winged creature will make the matter known.
Cast your bread upon the surface of the waters, for after many days you shall find it.
Give a portion to seven, and also to eight, for you do not know what evil shall be upon the earth.
If the clouds are filled with rain, they pour it out upon the earth; and if a tree falls in the south or in the north, in the place where the tree falls, there it shall lie.
He who watches the wind will not sow, and he who looks at the clouds will not reap.
As you do not know the way of the wind, nor how the bones grow in the womb of her who is with child, so you do not know the work of God who does all things.
In the morning sow your seed, and in the evening do not let your hand rest; for you do not know which will prosper, whether this or that, or whether both together will be alike good.
And the light is sweet, and it is good for the eyes to behold the sun.
For if a man lives many years, let him rejoice in them all; yet let him remember the days of darkness, for they will be many. All that comes is vanity.

Rejoice, young man, in your youth, and let your heart cheer you in the days of your young manhood, and walk in the ways of your heart and in the sight of your eyes; but know that for all these things God will bring you into judgment.
So remove vexation from your heart, and put away evil from your flesh, for youth and the dawn of life are vanity.
Remember also your Creator in the days of your youth, before the evil days come and the years draw near of which you will say, “I have no pleasure in them.”
Before the sun and the light and the moon and the stars grow dark, and the clouds return after the rain.
In the day when the keepers of the house tremble, and the strong men are bent, and the grinders cease because they are few, and those who look out of the windows are darkened.
And the doors shall be shut in the street, when the sound of the grinding is low; and one shall rise up at the voice of a bird, and all the daughters of song shall be brought low.

Also they shall be afraid of what is high, and terrors shall be in the way; and the almond tree shall blossom, and the grasshopper shall drag itself along, and desire shall fail, for man is going to his everlasting house, and the mourners go about in the street.
Before the silver cord is loosed, and the golden bowl is shattered, and the pitcher is broken at the spring, and the wheel is crushed into the cistern.
And the dust returns to the earth as it was, and the spirit returns to God who gave it.
Vanity of vanities, says the Preacher; all is vanity.
And moreover, because the Preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge; he weighed and searched out, and arranged many proverbs.
The Preacher sought to find words of delight, and that which was written is upright, words of truth.
The words of the wise are like goads, and like nails firmly planted are the collected sayings, given by one Shepherd.
And furthermore, my son, be warned: of making many books there is no end, and much study is a weariness to the flesh.
The end of the matter, all has been heard: fear God and keep His commandments, for this is the whole of man.
For God will bring every deed into judgment, with every hidden thing, whether it is good or whether it is evil.
